importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the publication of a news article detailing the severe air pollution in New Delhi during Diwali festivities, highlighting a recurring environmental crisis in the region.
The start date of the Diwali festival celebrations, which triggered widespread fireworks and contributed to the spike in air pollution in New Delhi and surrounding areas.
The end date of Diwali festivities, indicating the time window during which pollution from fireworks peaked and continued to affect air quality.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Diwali festival period from October 18 to 23, during which fireworks were set off, directly contributing to hazardous air quality in New Delhi and neighboring regions.
The period following the Diwali celebrations during which air quality in New Delhi remains at 'Very Poor to Poor' levels, indicating ongoing pollution due to residual emissions and seasonal smog.

keyTakeAways: New Delhi's air quality reached a hazardous level of 442 on Diwali night, more than 59 times the WHO’s safe PM2.5 annual limit.
The widespread use of fireworks during Diwali significantly worsened pollution, despite a Supreme Court-issued temporary allowance for 'green crackers' with lower emissions.
India's Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) classified the air quality as 'very poor' with an AQI of 350, emphasizing the severity of the issue.
Lahore, Pakistan, recorded a high AQI of 234, showing transboundary pollution from Indian Punjab and agricultural fires affecting regional air quality.
India’s winter smog is exacerbated by cold, stagnant air trapping emissions from traffic, industry, construction, and crop burning.
The government has previously implemented measures like school closures, vehicle restrictions, and anti-smog guns to combat pollution, but results remain inconsistent.
Last November, Delhi experienced a deadly smog event with an AQI exceeding 1,700, illustrating the long-term health and environmental risks of uncontrolled pollution.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the Diwali festival in October 2025, New Delhi experienced one of the most hazardous air pollution events globally, with its air quality index (AQI) reaching 442 due to widespread fireworks and seasonal smog. The concentration of PM2.5 particles exceeded 59 times the World Health Organization’s recommended annual limit, prompting the Central Pollution Control Board to classify the air as 'very poor'. Despite a Supreme Court permit for limited use of 'green crackers', fireworks were set off beyond the allowed times, worsening pollution. The situation is compounded by cold, stagnant air that traps emissions from traffic, industry, and agricultural fires in Punjab, India. Transboundary pollution is evident in Lahore, Pakistan, where AQI reached 234, indicating shared regional environmental challenges. Authorities have previously responded with school closures and vehicle restrictions, but long-term solutions remain elusive, highlighting a persistent threat to public health across South Asia.
title: Diwali provokes ‘hazardous’ alert over New Delhi air quality
